listing.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The Business Times earlier reported that the company posted a net loss of S$2.3 million on a revenue of S$79,440 for FY2024. This followed net losses of S$1.2 million for FY2023, and S$1.1 million for FY2022. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>For the first quarter of 2025, its net loss was S$706,391. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Back in May, MetaOptics was one of three companies to bag top honours at BT’s inaugural Design AI and Tech Awards, a competition that aims to spur innovators to harness design and technology to develop groundbreaking solutions that tackle real-life business challenges.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><strong><u><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:24.0pt;font-family:ArialMT;color:#4F81BD;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>8PR </span></u></strong></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><strong><u><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:24.0pt;font-family:ArialMT;color:#FFC000;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>ASIA</span></u></strong></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><b><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Yangzijiang Shipbuilding leads gains; STI up 0.2%</span></b></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Across the broader market, gainers beat losers 313 to 225, after 1.4 billion securities worth S$1.3 billion change hands<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Across the broader market, gainers beat losers 313 to 225, with 1.4 billion securities worth S$1.3 billion changing hands. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>[SINGAPORE] The local bourse started the week on a positive note, contrary to cautious sentiments in regional markets.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2 per cent or 6.37 points to 4,276.07 on Monday (Sep 1). Across the broader market, gainers beat losers 313 to 225, after 1.4 billion securities worth S$1.3 billion changed hands.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Yangzijiang Shipbuilding : BS6 +6.53% led the gains among the STI constituents, up 6.5 per cent or S$0.19 to S$3.10, after it announced new orders worth US$920 million.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Venture Corporation : V03 -2.43% was the biggest decliner on the index, down 2.4 per cent or S$0.33 at S$13.25 on a cum dividend basis.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Regional markets closed mixed as investors await the August US jobs report that will have a significant bearing on the possibility of a September rate cut. A softening labour market is seen as pressure on the Federal Reserve to cut rates, provided inflation remains contained.  <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Japan’s Nikkei 225 dropped 1.2 per cent, South Korea’s Kospi fell 1.4 per cent, but Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index climbed 2.2 per cent.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Christian Gattiker, head of research at Julius Baer, wrote in a note on Monday that the US non-farm payrolls report on Friday will anchor the week and shape expectations ahead of the Federal Reserve’s September meeting. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>“A print near July’s modest 73,000 gain, coupled with a higher unemployment rate, could keep hopes alive for a rate cut – but will not make the case decisive,” he noted. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Meanwhile, political risks cloud market outlooks in South-east Asia’s largest economy. Indonesia’s Jakarta Stock Exchange Composite Index dropped 1.2 per cent on Monday after heightened protests over the weekend. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>OCBC’s senior Asean economist Lavanya Venkateswaran and Asean economist Ahmad Enver highlighted the uncertainty over “defining changes in policy direction” by President Prabowo Subianto’s administration, given the protests. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>“We maintain our 2025 GDP growth forecast of 4.7 per cent (for Indonesia) and continue to expect another 25 basis-point rate cut from Bank Indonesia for the rest of this year,” they wrote in a note.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><b><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Milestones in annual reporting: Beyond yesterday’s numbers, towards tomorrow’s impact</span></b></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>It is no longer enough for annual reports to simply disclose more. Disclosures must be meaningful and relevant to investors – and AI will change how such reports are created and consumed<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>MILESTONES are not simply markers of time. They are moments that invite reflection, to pause and acknowledge achievements with gratitude, and to look ahead with renewed perspective and determination.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>This year, Singapore celebrates its 60th anniversary, a remarkable testament to six decades of resilience, unity and transformation. The Singapore Corporate Awards (SCA) marks its 20th anniversary, cementing its place as the stage on which excellence in corporate governance and reporting is recognised. Coincidentally, my own home institution, the NUS Business School, turns 60 this year as well.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>For those of us reflecting on the evolution of business and governance in Singapore, 2025 is nothing short of a milestone year.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Since its inception, the SCA, organised by the Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (Isca), the Singapore Institute of Directors (SID) and The Business Times, has been synonymous with raising standards of corporate governance practices in Singapore.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Within this constellation of awards, the Best Annual Report Award (ARA) has stood as a beacon of exemplary corporate reporting. At this juncture, as the SCA turns 20, it feels fitting to reflect on how far annual reporting has come, and how the ARA has evolved over the years.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Two decades ago, annual reports were quite different creatures. The emphasis was mostly on ensuring compliance with statutory requirements.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The ARA rewarded companies that produced complete, high-quality and well-presented financial disclosures. Sustainability elements were minimal, and often relegated to side notes. Annual reports were largely static documents, designed to meet the letter of the rules rather than to tell the fuller story of the company.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Over time, the focus of annual reporting shifted profoundly as expectations of investors and stakeholders began to change.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Annual reports became a window into the company: its mission, strategies, risks and, increasingly, its impact on society and the environment. Compliance gradually gave way to communication.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Strategic storytelling<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The best annual reports today are strategic storytelling tools that weave together a company’s purpose, performance and prospects into a coherent whole. Sustainability reporting moved from the margins to the mainstream, and ESG disclosures are no longer optional extras, but core measures of corporate responsibility and long-term value creation.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The ARA has been a mirror to this transformation. From recognising those who excelled at clear financial disclosures, it now rewards those who tell a compelling, integrated story. Impact and accountability have become the heart of great reporting.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The winners of the 2025 ARA embody this shift, and exemplify the very best of what corporate reporting can achieve.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In the big-cap category (market capitalisation of S$1 billion and above), DBS Group Holdings clinched the Gold, with Singapore Telecommunications (Singtel) and Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation (OCBC) claiming the Silver and Bronze. The winners are distinguished by their integration of corporate mission, risk assessment, financial performance and ESG strategy into a seamless narrative that not only informed, but also inspired in equal measure.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In the mid-cap category (market capitalisation of $300 million to $1 billion), SBS Transit drove home the point that operational detail and forward-looking insight can ride comfortably side by side. Its gold-winning report was clear, structured and highly readable. Far East Orchard (Silver award) and Hong Leong Asia (Bronze Award) followed with commendable efforts that kept pace with rising expectations.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In the small-cap category (market capitalisation of under $300 million), Qian Hu shone with its informative and clear report. Close behind is Banyan Tree Holdings and Hotel Royal, the latter making its debut appearance with an innovative, comprehensive effort that earned it a place on the podium.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Among Reits and Business Trusts, CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust stood alone as the Gold winner, praised for its clear articulation of portfolio performance and substantive disclosures.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>While larger companies often have greater resources to produce more sophisticated reports, this year’s results show that excellence is not a matter of size. Mid- and smaller-cap winners demonstrated that clarity of thought, relevance of disclosures to stakeholders and innovative presentations can be just as impactful.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Beyond financial figures<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>To lead the pack today, it is no longer enough to simply disclose more; rather, the disclosures must be meaningful, coherent and relevant. That includes minimising boilerplate language, using visuals to clarify rather than to decorate, and maintaining a consistent voice that reflects the company’s character and strategy.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The common thread observed by the ARA judging panel among all the winners was their ability to provide information that investors find useful.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Today, investors and stakeholders look well beyond the financial numbers. They seek context, perspective and insight into what drives performance. They want clarity on the market environment, the risks a company faces and the strategies it employs to navigate them effectively and responsibly.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Forward-looking perspectives are valued as much as historical performance, and transparency is expected, not only in celebrating successes but also in acknowledging setbacks and challenges. For companies, meeting these expectations brings tangible benefits, from strengthening investor confidence to deepening stakeholder trust.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>But milestones are not only about looking back, they are also about charting the way forward.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In his recent SG60 National Day message, Prime Minister Lawrence Wong reminded us that progress depends on drawing strength from the past while pressing forward with confidence.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>At these crossroads, the question naturally arises: where is annual reporting heading? Yet, perhaps the more critical question is not merely one of direction, but of aspiration. What should we, as a business community, envision annual reporting becoming?<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The answer is already beginning to take shape.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>ESG will and should remain at the forefront. The focus, however, is shifting from broad intentions to measurable impact.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Investors and stakeholders increasingly expect quantified results tied directly to corporate strategy and financial performance. Global standards set by, for example, the International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB) will help ensure comparability, while external assurance on sustainability data will likely become the norm rather than the exception, cementing credibility.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Sustainability should not appear as a detached insert; it should be woven seamlessly into the fabric of the company’s story, so that readers are not left burdened with piecing together two separate reports.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Static, text-heavy PDF reports will increasingly give way to digital-first formats that are more interactive, visual and engaging. Reports of the future will be living documents, rich with user-friendly visualisation and dashboards that enable stakeholders to explore trends and performance with greater ease and depth.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The most compelling reports will be those that connect strategy, risk, financials and ESG into one coherent story that informs decisions.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>On to the next milestones<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Looking ahead, artificial intelligence (AI) will almost certainly reshape how annual reports are created and consumed. As AI capabilities expand, so too will the demand for real-time reporting.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>For companies, AI tools can streamline production, detect inconsistencies, enhance data visualisation and generate timely updates. For readers, AI offers more dynamic and personalised experiences, so users can query the information in real time and receive tailored, evidence-based responses specific to their needs.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>These possibilities are exciting and will open new avenues of engagement, but they will also bring new responsibilities. Ensuring that AI-generated content remains accurate, authentic, and aligned with reporting standards will be critical.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>As Nelson Mandela once said: “Remember to celebrate milestones as you prepare for the road ahead.”<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Singapore’s 60 years of dynamic nation-building, the SCA’s 20 years of recognising excellence, and the ARA’s journey from past to present all remind us that progress is built on the foundations of yesterday, but sustained by the choices we make today for tomorrow. The challenge now is to keep evolving.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Annual reports must continue to innovate, embrace technology with responsibility, and integrate financial and non-financial performance into a single compelling narrative. Above all, they must remain grounded in transparency, because trust is the currency on which long-term value is built.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Milestones are not end points, but markers along the road. As we celebrate the ARA winners of 2025, we do so with the knowledge that the next chapter will demand even more.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The future of annual reporting will belong to those who can combine the rigour of transparency and accuracy with the art of storytelling, who can harness technology while preserving the irreplaceable human touch, and who understand that excellence is not a destination, but a continuous journey.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><strong><u><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:24.0pt;font-family:ArialMT;color:#4F81BD;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>8PR </span></u></strong></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><strong><u><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:24.0pt;font-family:ArialMT;color:#FFC000;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>ASIA</span></u></strong></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span This excludes about 500 coffee shops, markets and market-produce shops.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Other businesses said they have had to downsize to smaller units.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In March 2024, mobile phone retailer Erajaya moved from its 500 sq ft unit in the atrium area of HDB Hub in Toa Payoh to a smaller 300 sq ft unit in a nearby block, after its private landlord asked for a 20 per cent to 30 per cent increase in rent. Our margins are small given the high rental,” said the 45-year-old.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Commuters passing by Singtel mobile phone retailer Erajaya’s shop in a row of HDB retail units at the foot of Block 190 Lorong 6 Toa Payoh during the evening rush hour on Jun 19. lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>[SINGAPORE] The picture for Singapore’s hotel sector in the second quarter was not pretty. However, the sector’s performance in July showed improvement from the year-ago period. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In Q2 2025, the Republic’s hotels posted an average room rate (ARR) of S$263.83, down 1.1 per cent from the year-ago period’s S$266.89, according to Singapore Tourism Board (STB) data.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Average occupancy rate for hotels here slipped from 78.2 per cent in Q2 2024 to 77.8 per cent in the second quarter. As such, revenue per available room (RevPAR) fell 1.7 per cent to S$205.15 in Q2 2025, from S$208.77 in Q2 2024.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>On the supply front, there were 5.9 million available room nights in Q2 2025, up 2.4 per cent from the year-ago quarter.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Meanwhile, on the demand side, observers noted that the US-tariff-related uncertainty may have led to delayed or cancelled travel plans and muted the willingness of business and leisure travellers to spend. Furthermore, the strong Singapore dollar did not help.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Unsurprisingly, listed trusts which are major owners of hotels here, such as CDL Hospitality Trusts : J85 +1.89% and Far East Hospitality Trust, : Q5T +0.85% posted weaker financial performance – both trusts declared style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>However, STB’s data showed ARR, average occupancy rate and RevPAR of Singapore’s hotels rose year on year (yoy) in July 2025, with RevPAR at S$250.78, up 3.8 per cent yoy. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>MBS’ performance<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Nonetheless, even as the hotel sector faces uncertainties, integrated resort Marina Bay Sands (MBS), which fronts style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>For the quarter ended June, MBS’ owner New York-listed Las Vegas Sands (LVS) reported that MBS’ ARR for Q2 2025 grew to US$888 from US$797 in Q2 2024, up 11.4 per cent yoy. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span quarter RevPAR climbed 11.2 per cent yoy to US$844.  <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>MBS is outperforming the luxury tier of Singapore hotels. According to STB data, for the months of April to June, the ARR of the luxury tier of hotels ranged from S$630.64 to S$648.11 while occupancy rate was between 76.25 per cent and 78.99 per cent.  <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Perhaps, MBS’ strong performance is due to its scale and unique offering.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Today, MBS has 775 suites and 1,069 rooms. In each of the last four years, MBS employed over 10,000 full-time employees.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The integrated resort’s retail offering – The Shoppes at MBS – has a sizeable 620,513 sq ft of gross lettable area and hosts numerous flagship stores of major brands. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>MBS is central to the meetings, incentives, conventions, and exhibitions (Mice) business in Singapore. There are over 300,000 sq ft of exhibition halls at Sands Convention and Exhibition Centre. Also, MBS has 21 ballrooms of varying sizes, including the largest, the Sands Grand Ballroom, which can accommodate up to 8,000 guests.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Add to all of the above, centrally located MBS boasts great dining spots, the Republic’s largest nightclub Marquee, a casino, a skypark with the world’s longest infinity pool, an ArtScience Museum and iconic architecture.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>MBS shines not just in Singapore’s tourism scene but also relative to LVS’ Macau operations. According to  its latest earnings presentation, LVS has five integrated resorts with about 10,800 rooms and suites in Macau.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>For Q2 2025, LVS reported that MBS’ adjusted property earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (Ebitda) was US$768 million while that of Macau operations was US$566 million. Adjusted property Ebitda margin of MBS was 55.3 per cent versus 31.5 per cent for Macau operations.  <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>MBS’ expansion<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Given MBS’ success, LVS can confidently embark on major expansion plans for MBS, despite geopolitical tensions and US’ trade tariffs affecting the economic growth outlook globally and in Singapore.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In May, piling and foundation work commenced on MBS’ US$8 billion expansion project, with construction estimated to be completed in mid-2030. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The project will introduce a new 570-suite hotel, a 15,000-seat arena, additional Mice capacity and entertainment offerings including premium gaming areas.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Certainly, MBS has contributed enormously to Singapore’s economic growth and her appeal as an exciting global city.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>MBS has created many jobs as well as sourcing and procurement opportunities for Singapore-based small and medium enterprises. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The integrated resort’s expansion project can help to substantially strengthen the city-state’s appeal to luxury travellers, as a key Mice destination and as a leading venue for global entertainment events among others.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>For sure, MBS’ success has generated some tailwinds for Singapore’s hospitality sector. And MBS’ expansion project could further benefit other hotels here.  <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Think of how MBS draws more leisure visitors here, with many of these visitors visiting the integrated resort but staying elsewhere in the city-state. Or how MBS hosts Mice events that attract international visitors who stay at accommodation islandwide.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Imagine too how the new 15,000-seat arena could host top live musical performances which draw visitors from the region, thus driving demand for the entire hotel sector here. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>However, MBS is grabbing significant market share, be it in the high-end hotel, luxury retail, premier dining or nightlife segments, which can hurt other owners of properties targeting these segments.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>For example, sought-after luxury leisure travellers to Singapore might choose to stay at MBS despite MBS’ room rates being higher than numerous top-tier hotels because of its unique offerings and resist swapping staying at the integrated resort for what may be inferior substitutes.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>With MBS being big and successful, and growing even bigger, expect it to hog talent in the Republic’s hospitality industry, which faces manpower challenges as many locals may shun working in an industry where hours can be long and working nights and on weekends could be required.    <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Given its scale, MBS is well-placed to offer employees better perks, training and career development opportunities relative to other smaller hotels here. Indeed, the integrated resort is widely recognised as an employer of choice.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Ultimately, Singapore gains from MBS flourishing and growing. However, while this giant brings some business to the wider hotel sector here, it also makes the going much tougher for other top-tier hotels in attracting demand for rooms, dining outlets and events.   <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><strong><u><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:24.0pt;font-family:ArialMT;color:#FFC000;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>ASIA</span></u></strong></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The deputy prime minister is also visiting Shenzhen and Beijing during his five-day trip<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>[SINGAPORE] The China-Singapore Guangzhou Knowledge City (CSGKC) is a useful test bed for the development of new technologies and will continue to support knowledge-sharing, leaders of the two regions said on Monday (Sep 1).<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Singapore’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MFA) said this in a statement after Deputy Prime Minister (DPM) Gan Kim Yong visited the CSGKC, a state-level bilateral project that marks its 15th anniversary this year. While in Guangzhou, he met Guangdong Governor Wang Weizhong, who also hosted him to lunch.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>DPM Gan’s trip to the 232 square kilometre township was the first stop in his five-day working visit to China that began on Sunday.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>On Monday, he visited the National University of Singapore Guangzhou Research Translation and Innovation Institute, the DBS Global Fintech R&D Centre, and agritech startup Singrow.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>These are among the more than 50 Singapore companies currently based in CSGKC, which has served as a key landing pad for them to access the Greater Bay Area.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In its statement, MFA said that DPM Gan and Wang reaffirmed the strong economic collaboration and longstanding people-to-people ties between Singapore and Guangdong.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Guangdong has been Singapore’s top provincial trading partner in China for the last 36 consecutive years, noted MFA. “Beyond trade, our robust cooperation has expanded to a wide range of sectors, including advanced manufacturing, digital economy, intellectual property rights protection, education and healthcare,” the ministry added.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Apart from Guangzhou, DPM Gan is also visiting Shenzhen and Beijing. On Wednesday, he will attend a series of commemorative events marking the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>This is his first visit to China since becoming DPM. His trip comes about two months after Prime Minister Lawrence Wong made his first official visit to Beijing and Tianjin, at the invitation of Chinese Premier Li Qiang.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><b><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Time is running out for Singapore’s oldest HDB flats as prices flatten and demand slows </span></b></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>As demand dwindles for older HDB flats, questions remain over how a voluntary redevelopment scheme will change the market<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>[SINGAPORE] Nearly 300 blocks of Singapore’s oldest Housing & Development Board (HDB) flats are entering the final 30-year stretch of their 99-year leases – and data points to a shrinking resale market and flattening prices for these ageing properties.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Asking prices and resale values for the first HDB flats built in the 1960s have held up as the resale market on the whole continued to rise, especially over the last five years. But set against the broader market and compared to valuations, the picture is less rosy.   <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Data crunched by property listing platform PropertyGuru for The Business Times indicates that median asking prices of HDB flats built in the 1960s held steady in the past year, up 1.6 per cent to S$375,000. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>ERA key executive officer Eugene Lim said many of these old flats in sought-after mature estates witnessed substantial price growth in the last five years despite their age, in tandem with the overall resale market. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In the first seven months of 2025, the median price of three-room flats built in the 1960s ranged from S$335,000 to S$380,000 – up by between 30 per cent and 60 per cent compared to their median in 2020 at between S$220,000 and S$275,000. That of two-room flats likewise rose from S$188,000-S$207,000 in 2020, to S$285,000-S$301,888 in 2025. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Old four-room flats in Queenstown even hit a median price of S$899,000 in 2025, though Lim noted that the transactions were for terraced houses, which are rare and tend to draw high prices. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Set against a longer time frame, gains shrink. Huttons Asia senior director of data analytics Lee Sze Teck pointed out that compared to 2013, prices of the oldest two-room and three-room flats are 5.8 to 5.9 per cent higher today.  <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In comparison, prices of two-room flats built in the 1970s rose by 15.5 per cent between 2013 and 2025, and that of three-room flats by 12.4 per cent. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Lee Nai Jia, PropertyGuru head of real estate intelligence, data and software solutions, noted that the 1.6 per cent rise in asking prices for the 60s era flats is modest compared to the 10.3 per cent increase observed in the broader resale market. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Nicholas Mak, chief research officer at property portal </span></span><a href="https://protect2.fireeye.com/v1/url?k=f6cc0ec3-9267a163-f6c8bbf5-3cecefeaf2ae-3b3844e623305b15&q=1&e=1484d211-6cd4-420c-960c-be3e5e2f6097&u=http%3A%2F%2Fmogul.sg%2F"><span
