style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>, pointed to a mismatch between sellers’ expectations and valuations of these old HDBs. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Figures from </span></span><a href="https://protect2.fireeye.com/v1/url?k=b77fe1f4-d3d44e54-b77b54c2-3cecefeaf2ae-bdb262d9b2d330fb&q=1&e=1484d211-6cd4-420c-960c-be3e5e2f6097&u=http%3A%2F%2Fmogul.sg%2F"><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Mogul.sg</span></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'></span></a><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'> showed that the median asking price of 1960s HDB flats ranged from S$309,000 to S$1.75 million this year, with the lowest for two-room flats and the highest for terraced houses. The median asking price of three-room flats, which comprised the bulk of listings on the portal, was S$388,888. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Meanwhile, median valuations ranged between S$316,000 and S$847,000 for these flats. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>“This suggests that two-room flats may be underpriced on the market, whereas five-room flats and terraced houses appear to be overpriced,” said Mak. Three-room flats, in particular, had a median valuation of S$336,000, which was far below their median asking price of S$388,888. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Lee from PropertyGuru said demand for 60s era flats has been trending downwards. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>According to the platform’s data, impressions – or views – on resale listings for the oldest flats fell about 28 per cent year on year, a sharp drop compared to the overall resale market.  <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>As the government ramps up new public housing supply, Lee reckoned that demand for these older flats will only continue to dwindle, potentially placing downward pressure on prices. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>ERA’s Lim noted that transaction activity for these older flats has remained fairly stable in the past decade, ranging from 219 to 300 units a year. On average, 263 homes built in the 1960s change hands annually. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In the first seven months of 2025, 170 units were sold – tracking within historical norms. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Fewer transactions does not necessarily reflect weaker demand, and could be due to a limited supply of flats for sale, said Lim. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>On the rental front, Lee from PropertyGuru said listing impressions generally tracked the overall HDB rental trend. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>“While rental demand saw a decline from 2023 to 2024, it appears to have stabilised in 2025,” said Lee. Listings were typically room rentals, with average asking rent of around S$1,100 per month as at July 2025. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Cashing out<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Seniors seeking more immediate ways to monetise their homes can turn to HDB’s lease buyback scheme (LBS). <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Under the scheme, eligible seniors can sell part of their flat’s remaining lease to HDB, with proceeds topping up their CPF Retirement Account and purchasing a CPF Life plan, which provides monthly payouts for life. Any excess will be returned to them in cash, <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>As at Dec 31, 2024, 13,734 households have taken up LBS. Of these, about 52 per cent lived in three-room or smaller flats, around 34 per cent lived in four-room flats, and the remaining 14 per cent in five-room or bigger flats. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The vast majority of households at 90 per cent retain lease lengths of 20 to 30 years, said HDB, allowing seniors to “supplement their retirement income while ageing”. The remaining households were evenly split between 15-year and 35-year leases.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>HDB added that after selling part of their remaining leases to HDB, around nine in 10 households received proceeds of between S$100,000 and S$300,000. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>This value is before the top-up to their CPF retirement account, and depends on the market value of the flats and duration of the lease retained, it said. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Seniors can also receive a cash bonus when they right-size to a smaller public housing flat with the silver housing bonus. As at Dec 2024, 2,535 households have benefitted from the bonus. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Ageing flats, shrinking value<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Figures from ERA indicated that there are 299 HDB blocks built in the 1960s, with 24,428 units in total. Most are concentrated in Queenstown, Toa Payoh, Bukit Merah and Geylang, with smaller clusters in Kallang Whampoa and the Central area. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>One of the government’s objectives when it launched the public housing programme in the 1960s was to ease overcrowding in the city centre by providing affordable flats in the city fringe area, Mak said. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Most of these 60s-era flats are three-room and four-room flats, statistics from </span></span><a href="https://protect2.fireeye.com/v1/url?k=f7dc303f-93779f9f-f7d88509-3cecefeaf2ae-f7268b3f006b3b38&q=1&e=1484d211-6cd4-420c-960c-be3e5e2f6097&u=http%3A%2F%2Fmogul.sg%2F"><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Mogul.sg</span></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'></span></a><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'> showed. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Analysts expect these ageing flats to follow the trajectory observed in older private leasehold homes. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>According to Huttons’ Lee, prices of 60-year leasehold terraced houses at Lorong 3 Geylang tapered off sharply as their leases came to an end. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In 2013, units transacted for over S$200,000. This fell to just over S$150,000 in 2014, equivalent to annual rent of S$33,000; declining further to over S$100,000 in 2015, equivalent to annual rent of S$30,000; before dropping to around S$50,000 in 2017 and 2018, equivalent to annual rent of S$25,000. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The land occupied by these houses returned to the state when their leases expired on Dec 31, 2020. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Singapore attempted to address issues related to rebuilding ageing housing estates with the selective en bloc redevelopment scheme (Sers), launched in 1995. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Under the compulsory scheme, old HDB blocks were demolished and rebuilt. Homeowners were compensated based on market value and given the option to buy a replacement flat nearby with a fresh 99-year lease. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In 2022, households in Ang Mo Kio whose flats were picked for Sers received compensation of up to S$450,000. Those flats were completed in 1979 and were about 43 years old then.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>On top of that, flat owners received a grant of S$30,000, a removal allowance of S$10,000, and payment of stamp and legal fees for the purchase of a replacement flat equivalent in value to their Sers flat.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Mak said the “attractive terms” led some buyers to pay “top dollar” for flats aged 40 years or more, in hopes of being picked for Sers. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>“(It) cultivated the mindset among HDB resale flat buyers that Sers is some sort of safety net for owners of older flats,” he said, “a kind of government bailout for owners of ageing flats”.  <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>This fuelled price growth of these older flats, said Mak. “However, Sers is an expensive exercise for the government, and with the growing number of ageing flats, it is unsustainable in the long run.” <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Earlier in August, Minister for National Development Chee Hong Tat said the government does not plan to continue Sers, but instead will focus on a voluntary early redevelopment scheme (Vers), first surfaced in 2018.  <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Analysts said this could prove tricky. If the scheme mirrors private collective sales, it may be difficult to secure the 80 per cent consent required from owners, with thorny questions over how to handle those who refuse. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Residents who collectively decide not to proceed with it may live in their flats until the leases run out, Chee said. “The government will support them in other ways to keep their flats and their estates liveable and vibrant.”<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Compensation is another sticking point. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Valuations are expected to be guided by market benchmarks, but leasehold values fall steeply as leases run down. Lee from Huttons cites the leasehold table informally known as Bala’s Curve in real estate circles. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Based on the table, the value of land with 30 years remaining is 60 per cent of the freehold value, said Lee. This plunges to 30 per cent when only 10 years remain. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Older flat owners may not want to move or sell if it means having to get in line for a new Build-to-Order flat, or pay for a higher-priced resale flat. “The level of interest may be lukewarm, and prices may remain relatively flat during this period of uncertainty,” said Lee. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Vers could still appeal to those seeking a more affordable home with “a potential safety net”, said PropertyGuru’s Lee. “Over time, Vers may help stabilise demand for older flats and offer a monetisation option for households who may need it.”<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><strong><u><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:24.0pt;font-family:ArialMT;color:#4F81BD;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>8PR </span></u></strong></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><strong><u><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:24.0pt;font-family:ArialMT;color:#FFC000;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>ASIA</span></u></strong></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><b><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Prive group put up for sale more than a year before closure; no takers in tough market</span></b></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The F&B group tried all options to stay in business to no avail, says group chairman Yuan Oeij<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>THE Prive group, which suddenly announced the closure of all its restaurants on Monday (Sep 1), had been on the market for over a year but failed to find any takers in a troubled F&B industry.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Group chairman Yuan Oeij said: “We (did) our best to ensure the continuity of our business and speak with interested parties – whether investors or partners – to explore different options.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>“However, given the extremely tough climate for the F&B industry, everyone has been taking a very cautious stance.”<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The Business Times understands that the group was put up for sale in March 2024 at an asking price of S$20 million. At the time, it had 12 Prive outlets and two restaurants – Empress and Prive Grill. class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>“Indonesia’s economic conditions are relatively stable, though not outstanding. If investor confidence is not restored, short-term economic instability may occur,” he added.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The economy grew by an annual 5.12 per cent in the second quarter, the fastest pace in two years, according to official data.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Mr Airlangga said a programme giving free meals to students and pregnant women would be accelerated, and there would be new incentives such as loans for investment in property and labour-intensive sectors, adding that a task force would look into job creation opportunities. REUTERS<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><b><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Jakarta protests ease after pay hike for lawmakers is reversed, but style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>An analyst warns that if the government’s response is seen as inadequate – or delayed – prolonged demonstrations could hurt private-sector investment and dampen spending on durable goods and tourism<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>[JAKARTA] Protests in Jakarta, marked by vandalism and looting that damaged infrastructure, eased slightly on Monday (Sep 1) after President Prabowo Subianto scrapped a planned pay hike for lawmakers, but not before causing an estimated nine trillion rupiah (S$770 million) in economic losses, particularly in the Greater Jakarta area. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The retail, transportation and services sectors were hit hardest with the services sector – nearly half of the national economy – suffering a sharp three-day decline, indicated the Center for Economic and Law Studies (Celios).  <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Businesses and analysts still remain cautious. Nailul Huda, digital economy director at Celios, warned that the situation remains delicate although the angst appears to have cooled. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Ari Jahja, head of Indonesia research at Macquarie Capital, said that investors are awaiting Prabowo’s next steps, be it to address public demands or restore market confidence. “Indonesia could emerge stronger if structural reforms are successfully implemented,” he added.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Indonesia’s stock exchange closed down 1.21 per cent on Monday, while the rupiah strengthened 0.33 per cent, following a stronger-than-expected trade surplus in July.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Damage tolls<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Violent protests in Jakarta damaged public transport infrastructure, with 22 TransJakarta bus stops vandalised, burned or looted, Governor Pramono Anung said on Monday. He estimated total losses at 55 billion rupiah.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Protests in Jakarta subsided on Monday after days of unrest and looting, as some demonstrators held back following weekend riots. In Makassar, where last weekend’s protests left four people dead, students marched to the local parliament building demanding justice for the victims, Kompas newspaper reported. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>A few mass demonstrations continued outside the parliament building in Central Jakarta, though in smaller numbers than last weekend. Police deployed around 5,000 personnel to secure the area, Central Jakarta Police Chief Commissioner Susatyo Purnomo Condro said.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Protests are expected to continue in the coming days, with demonstrators urging Prabowo to enact policy reforms, including a review of the costly free lunch programme and redirecting its budget towards initiatives that could generate jobs and curb lay-offs.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The Indonesian Student Alliance, which had planned to stage another protest outside parliament, said it decided not to return to the streets on Monday after last week’s rally ended in violence. Prabowo had earlier ordered firm action against violent protesters and increased security at key sites. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Unrests in Jakarta have led to cancellations at hotels and restaurants, particularly in the city centre. Hariyadi Sukamdani, chairman of Indonesia Hotel and Restaurants Association, noted that cancellations began on Friday after demonstrations escalated and turned deadly, driven not only by safety concerns but also by heavy traffic and restricted access to central areas.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>He added that while hotels and restaurants are still operating normally, the risk of temporary closures remains if tensions flare up again. “There is still anxiety that the unrest could escalate, so we have advised hotels to strengthen their security,” he noted.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Helmi Arman, Citi’s chief economist for Indonesia, warned that if the government’s response is seen as inadequate -– or delayed – prolonged protests could hurt private-sector investment and dampen spending on durable goods and tourism. “It is unclear to us at this juncture what kind of corrective actions it would take to appease the protests,” he wrote in a note.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In Jakarta, military personnel were deployed to guard commercial facilities, including shopping malls and office towers, The Business Times observed. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Foot traffic in Jakarta’s Thamrin and Sudirman business districts was noticeably lighter than usual, as many offices implemented work-from-home arrangements amid lingering concerns that unrest could flare up again.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Public transport services, including TransJakarta and the mass rapid transit, resumed normal operations on Monday after being targeted by protesters. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Growth risks<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Analysts said that rising political tensions in Indonesia are heightening economic risks, especially in the wake of the 19 per cent US tariffs that came into effect in August.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In a note, OCBC economists Lavanya Venkateswaran and Ahmad Enver noted that the impact of the tariffs is likely to start showing in August data. They projected that the economy will slow to 4.5 per cent in the second half of the year, down from 5 per cent in the first half, reflecting the combined effects of external and domestic pressures.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>They added: “It remains to be seen whether the protests will prompt any significant policy changes under the Prabowo administration, but this is not our base case.”<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In a note, S&P Global Ratings analysts said that protests in several cities are unlikely to escalate to a level that would undermine political stability. They added that policy adjustments could include measures to support the economy and boost social spending.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>However, the analysts warned that if economic pressures intensify and fuel social tensions, it could become increasingly challenging for the government to lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The tight conditions have led the authorities to ask overseas customers to accept shipment delays and to urge exporters to defer cargoes well into 2026<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>[JAKARTA] Indonesia’s growing gas shortage is forcing the government to prioritise domestic industries – a decision which analysts said could undermine its credibility as an exporter and may push long-standing partners such as Singapore to look elsewhere. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The supply crunch will also have a “severe impact” on Indonesia’s gas-reliant manufacturers – from those in fertilisers and petrochemicals to ceramics and steel – as they face operational strain, threatening a fallout in investments and jobs.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Already, the tight conditions have led the authorities to ask overseas gas customers to accept shipment delays and to urge exporters to defer cargoes well into 2026, a decision which holds significant implications for importers.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Pang Lu Ming, senior analyst at Rystad Energy, said that while sellers and buyers may reallocate volumes, the original terms of the contract must still be honoured. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>“Deviations from the contract should be accounted for in specific clauses within the contract which may allow for a swap of volumes,” he noted. “If there are any deviations, negotiations and possible reparations will be required between the parties involved before further actions can be taken.”<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Responding to queries from The Business Times, the Energy Market Authority (EMA) said that Singapore’s natural gas supply remains stable. “EMA will continue to closely monitor developments and work with industry partners to ensure Singapore’s energy security and price stability,” it added.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>To safeguard against potential disruptions, Singapore sources natural gas from a diverse range of suppliers, including liquefied natural gas (LNG) from around the world and piped natural gas from Malaysia.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Indonesia has been a pillar of South-east Asia’s gas trade, supplying Singapore through pipelines and shipping LNG cargoes to buyers across Asia and beyond for decades. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Now, with the gas crunch on, Indonesian factories and other industrial users are demanding more fuel just as production is slowing, making it a challenge for the country to both satisfy local needs and honour export commitments. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>BMI, a unit of Fitch Solutions, said that despite growth prospects for Indonesia LNG production, exports are unlikely to rise significantly in the near term as the government prioritises domestic consumption.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In the first half of this year, Indonesia’s total gas consumption hit 5,598 billion British thermal units (BTU) per day, with nearly 70 per cent consumed domestically, and the remainder exported, underscoring the ongoing balancing act between meeting local demand and overseas commitments.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources projects Indonesia’s natural gas demand to exceed 6,000 billion BTU per day between 2025 and 2030, driven by rising industrial consumption and the government’s energy-mix programme.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Swap deal<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>A multiparty gas swap was launched by SKK Migas, Indonesia’s upstream regulator, on Aug 22 to ease immediate domestic shortages while maintaining existing export contracts.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The arrangement redirects 27 billion BTU a day from the West Natuna Supply Group, which includes Medco E&P Natuna, Premier Oil Natuna Sea and Star Energy (Kakap), to state-owned gas distributor Perusahaan Gas Negara (PGN) for domestic delivery.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Physical volumes are transported through pipelines operated by Medco E&P Grissik and PetroChina International Jabung in South Sumatra, which channel natural gas from Indonesia to Singapore. The deal involves key upstream contractors and buyers, including state-owned Pertamina and overseas buyers such as Singapore’s Sembcorp Gas.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In March, Sembcorp announced that it had terminated the gas sales agreement its unit had signed to import piped natural gas from Indonesia’s Mako gas fields, citing regulatory hurdles. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Pang from Rystad Energy said that swaps occur only under long-term agreements, where the characteristics of the gas molecules are clearly defined. “This is usually possible in regions with well-integrated pipeline networks.”<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Natural gas powers more than 92 per cent of Singapore’s electricity, sourced mainly through pipelines from Malaysia and Indonesia. The rest is imported as LNG.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Balancing act<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Under President Prabowo Subianto, Indonesia is racing to boost industrialisation and achieve 8 per cent growth, but the recent gas crisis shows that the country is caught between a rock and a hard place, balancing rising domestic demand with declining output.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In an information disclosure report released on Aug 15, PGN said that gas distribution from upstream oil and gas contractors fell in August, temporarily disrupting deliveries to several customers in West Java and parts of Sumatra. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>PGN attributed the disruption to an unplanned shutdown at existing gas suppliers and delays in finalising additional supplies, which affected both required volumes and distribution stability in the affected areas. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Manufacturers then raised the alarm. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Seven manufacturing sub-sectors currently benefit from the government’s subsidised gas price programme, locally known as HGBT: fertiliser, petrochemicals, oleochemicals, steel, ceramics, glassware and rubber gloves. But recent cuts in allocations have led to operational strain. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Indonesian media reported that two tableware factories in Tangerang halted production and laid off around 700 workers earlier this month, citing gas supply restrictions.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The Ministry of Industry confirmed the pressure on manufacturers, with spokesperson Febri Hendri Antoni Arief warning that the shortage is hitting economic activity across sectors. “This crisis is having a severe impact on the manufacturing industry,” he said in a statement. “It affects not only manufacturers, but also investment sentiment, production processes and job creation.”<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Industry groups warned that the situation could worsen. Indonesia’s Olefin, Aromatic and Plastic Industry Association has criticised the government’s handling of the crisis, saying prolonged shortages could trigger mass layoffs.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Jakarta-based fatty acid manufacturer Sumi Asih reported that since Aug 13, it has been receiving less than half of its contracted gas volumes, which were initially capped at 48 per cent of the agreed quota and gradually lifted to around 70 per cent. This has left the company struggling to meet commitments to buyers in China and Europe.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In response to queries from BT, PGN said that the situation has been resolved, with industrial customers under the HGBT programme now receiving supplies based on the government’s reallocation scheme.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Temporary relief<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>However, industry experts cautioned that the respite may be short-lived without deeper structural reforms.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Prateek Pandey, senior vice-president at Rystad Energy, said that the swap could help secure additional volumes for the domestic market in the near term, likely through the end of this year and into next. “But over the longer horizon, Indonesia will need to either secure new long-term import contracts or accelerate the development of its substantial domestic resources,” he explained.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Indonesia’s LNG exports fell gradually from 17 million tonnes per annum (mtpa) in 2015 to 10 mtpa in 2023, largely due to declining output from the Tangguh and Bontang LNG plants and the government’s decision to prioritise domestic consumption.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Production in South Sumatra, home to key blocks such as Pertamina EP, the Corridor Block and Jambi Merang, has been steadily falling for five years.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Few new supply projects have come online to offset the declines, forcing regulators to redirect existing supplies to fertiliser plants, power stations and industrial users. New demand is also emerging, most notably from a power plant in Batam.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Upcoming projects such as the Abadi LNG project, Indonesia Deepwater Development and exploration in the Andaman Sea could theoretically meet both domestic and export demand, but delays remain a major risk.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>“Indonesia has enough potential to meet domestic demand while continuing exports,” Pandey said. “The real risk is delays in development, which could affect investor sentiment.”<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Indonesia is not alone in facing gas supply challenges. Malaysia may redirect more Sarawak output to domestic use, while Australia has long struggled to balance exports with local demand.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Pandey said that the broader lesson is that governments should focus on expanding supply rather than merely curbing exports. “Developing pipeline resources already in the works and improving connectivity is critical. Many pipelines require both investment and investor attention.” <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><strong><u><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:24.0pt;font-family:ArialMT;color:#4F81BD;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>8PR </span></u></strong></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><strong><u><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:24.0pt;font-family:ArialMT;color:#FFC000;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>ASIA</span></u></strong></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><b><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Indonesian stock, bond selloff extends after weekend of unrest</span></b></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>[JAKARTA] A sell-off in Indonesian stocks and bonds continued on Monday (Sep 1), weighed by growing concerns over political stability in South-east Asia’s biggest economy.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The country’s equity benchmark fell as much as 3.6 per cent, the most in nearly five months, before trimming losses to close down about 1.5 per cent, with financial shares including Bank Rakyat Indonesia among the biggest drags. The move came after protests heightened over the weekend in response to rising living costs and inequality. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Stress also was evident in the bond market, with yields on the nation’s benchmark 10-year government paper up seven basis points to 6.4 per cent, the highest in almost three weeks. The rupiah was steady as the central bank continued its intervention to keep the currency stable.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The rout in Indonesian stocks and debt that started Friday marks a reversal of investor mood, when some global funds had just started rotating back into South-east Asian assets given lower valuations and potential monetary easing. Political turbulence, which is also plaguing Thailand at the moment, heightens the risk of foreign capital outflows that have accelerated in recent days. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Indonesia’s “political risk will rise, and so will the equity risk premium,” said John Foo, founder of Valverde Investment Partners in Singapore. “We are underweight on Indonesia as the valuations do not reflect the underlying issues in the economy.” <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>President Prabowo Subianto cancelled a trip to China following the deadly unrest as demonstrators targeted the homes of Indonesia’s finance minister and several lawmakers. On Sunday, Prabowo announced parliament will remove hefty lawmaker perks that had been a source of ire for many protesters.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Outrage<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Protests in Indonesia were sparked last week by outrage over lawmakers’ housing allowances- nearly 10 times the monthly minimum wage in Jakarta – and fuelled by tax hikes, mass layoffs, and inflation that have disproportionately hit lower-income Indonesians.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Banks were among the biggest drags on the stock benchmark, with Bank Rakyat, Bank Central Asia, and Bank Mandiri Persero all down more than 4 per cent intraday.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Any capital outflows would first hit the financial sector, Prasetya Gunadi, head of equity research at Samuel Sekuritas Indonesia, wrote in a note. “Banks remain the most exposed, given their large index weight and potential liquidity stress if political instability triggers capital withdrawals.”<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Indonesia’s stock market attracted a net US$676 million from foreign investors in August, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. Its equity benchmark is up 8 per cent this year, having reached a record high before the unrest erupted.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>On the currency front, the rupiah is one of the weaker performers in Asia this year, down over 2 per cent against the greenback.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>“Indonesian stocks are poised for more declines with political risks clouding the outlook. The recent escalation weakens the outlook and raises the equity risk premium,” said Mary Nicola, MLIV macro strategist. “That will keep Indonesian assets under pressure, and likely unwind the inflows seen in August.”<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>BNY downgraded its outlook on the rupiah to neutral from positive on Monday, because of the near-term political factors, according to Wee Khoon Chong, a senior strategist in Hong Kong.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>“While we think such unrest is likely to be short-lived, investors will no doubt de-risk or confidence.”<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Thai woes <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Political turmoil is also rocking Thailand, style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Thailand has struggled for decades to overcome political infighting, contributing to slower economic growth compared with regional rivals. Anutin Charnvirakul, a conservative politician, claimed late on Friday to have sufficient support from lawmakers to become prime minister, saying the nation must not “come to a standstill.”<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Valverde’s Foo was comparatively sanguine about Thailand, citing cheap valuations and the hope that a new prime minister will stimulate the economy. “The market is ready for a change in PM in Thailand,” he said.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>For BNY’s Chong, the baht is likely to remain in its current trading range despite the rising political uncertainty, thanks in part to the downtrend in the US dollar. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Foreign investors have pulled US$670 million out of Thai stocks so far this year. The Thai equities benchmark has dropped about 12 per cent since 2025 began, with the baht up over 5 per cent against the US dollar.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Long-term outlook<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Nirgunan Tiruchelvam, an analyst at Aletheia Capital in Singapore, argued the current turbulence in both nations doesn’t “alter the long-term outlook” given the prospect of looser monetary policy and the valuations the bourses offer. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Prabowo has prioritised economic expansion and pursued a populist agenda since coming to power last year, including a massive free meals programme, raising some concerns about Indonesia’s fiscal outlook. Another signature initiative is a newly established sovereign wealth fund, Danantara, which oversees nearly 900 state firms and has reported US$1 trillion in assets under management.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The president’s policies have yet to alleviate the economic struggles faced by the lower-income population in Indonesia, said Xin-Yao Ng, an investment director at Aberdeen Investments. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>“I have remained concerned about the economic trajectory and am waiting to see what Danantara can achieve in this regard,” Ng said. lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>[BANGKOK] The biggest party in Thailand’s parliament held out on Monday (Sep 1) in deciding whom it would back to form the next government, prolonging lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The opposition People’s Party will not join any government but with control of nearly a third of the house seats, it is a potential kingmaker that can break the political deadlock caused by Friday’s dismissal of Paetongtarn Shinawatra by the Constitutional Court for an ethics violation.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Lawmakers of the People’s Party met on Monday to weigh the merits of backing Paetongtarn’s ruling Pheu Thai party, or Bhumjaithai, a renegade party that quit the governing coalition in June and is mounting its own bold challenge.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>“To be straight, we don’t trust either,” he said, when asked if the two camps would honour the party’s demands that a referendum be held on amending the partner Bhumjaithai and its ambitious leader Anutin Charnvirakul.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US candidate.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><b><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Asia-Pacific hotel deal value falls 23% to US$4.7 billion in H1 2025: class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>[SINGAPORE] Hotel investors have turned more cautious in the first half of 2025, deploying style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Asia-Pacific hotel transaction value stood at US$4.7 billion in H1, 23 per cent lower than the US$5.7 billion recorded in the same period in the previous year, according to JLL.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Japan continued to lead regional hotel investment with US$1.5 billion in transactions, followed by China which had US$744 million in deals. Investors spent US$664 million acquiring hotels in Australia, while in Singapore, they deployed US$546 million in the same period. South Korea rounded up the top markets, with US$504 million invested in the segment. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>JLL said: “Investors have gravitated to safe-haven markets, while decision-making timelines lengthened. At the same time, the bid-ask spread between seller expectations and buyer valuations has also widened with sellers holding firm on price expectations and buyers applying greater scrutiny, leading to extended due diligence periods on both sides of transactions.” <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>High-net-worth individuals from within the region emerged as increasingly active buyers in H1, seeking portfolio diversification through hotel investments, with capital invested into hotels growing 54 per cent from the same period last year. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In Singapore, investors gravitated towards boutique hotels. Duxton Reserve was sold in May 2025 for S$80 million, or about S$1.6 million per key. The 49-key boutique hotel was sold by Singapore-based hospitality company The Garcha Group to Lotus One Investment, the investment arm of Lotus Singapore, a family office focused on ventures in South Asia. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In April, the 48-key shophouse hotel 21 Carpenter was sold by 8M Real Estate to Indonesian-born, Singapore-based billionaire Leo KoGuan. According to industry sources, it was sold for S$100 million, or about S$2.1 million per key. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Hybrid hotels, with an extended-stay component, are also attracting investment from private-equity groups. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Tan Ling Wei, senior vice-president of investment sales at JLL Hotels & Hospitality Group, noted: “Singapore’s boutique hotel sector continues to attract private capital seeking both diversification and long-term capital value.” <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Looking ahead<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>For the full year, hotel transaction value in Singapore is projected to reach US$1.2 billion, JLL said. This is higher than the US$744 million recorded in 2024.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Across the entire Asia-Pacific region, hotel transaction value is expected to total US$12.8 billion, an almost 5 per cent increase from US$12.2 billion in 2024. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>“This forecast anticipates accelerated investment activity in the second half of the year as the backlog of deals in due diligence are expected to settle then,” noted JLL.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>It added: should ensure an uptick in activity in this year and into the next.”<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US
