back, but the whipsaw market conditions, including a new trend of late bookings, has undermined carriers’ ability to forecast demand<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>[DALLAS] Spirit Aviation Holdings’ second bankruptcy filing in a year signals that the low-cost carrier is finally facing up to the painful steps needed to ensure its survival.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>But its board faces daunting challenges on the path ahead, including how to downsize its fleet of leased aircraft while managing the roller coaster market conditions for US air travel that complicate the prospects for a long-term recovery.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>“The general criticism of the first bankruptcy is that Spirit wasn’t aggressive enough in cost-cutting and only using the filing to address debt to some extent (perhaps not enough even then),” Raymond James analyst Savanthi Syth wrote in an e-mail. “Spirit has been making many adjustments already since last fall. However, further cuts appear likely.”<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The bankruptcy, filed late on Friday (Aug 29) in New York, lists assets and liabilities of between US$1 billion and US$10 billion. The petition comes amid active negotiations with some of its largest lessors, secured noteholders and key stakeholders, the carrier said.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Spirit’s petition underscores the difficulty facing discount airlines in the US, from high labour costs to the ever-present struggle to grow enough to protect margins. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Much larger and more diversified carriers such as United Airlines Holdings and Delta Air Lines are adding to the pressure, selling “basic economy” fares to lure cost-sensitive passengers away from cheaper options at Spirit and rivals such as Allegiant Travel, Frontier Group Holdings and even Southwest Airlines. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Southwest is fighting back with an extensive makeover plan, offering premium fares with more legroom and assigned seats – breaking away from the one-size-fits-all business model it championed for five decades. Spirit and Frontier also have adjusted their business models to include upscale options.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Market turbulence <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>It’s unclear how dramatic an overhaul Spirit could pursue. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Ultra-low-cost carriers are hit harder when there’s too much capacity on routes, forcing them to cut fares at the expense of profits. Unlike the industry’s leaders, Spirit lacks long-haul international routes that can make up for weakened demand in the domestic market.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Spirit emerged from bankruptcy protection in March, while the US airline industry was in the midst of a sharp decline in flying by consumers concerned with US President Donald Trump’s trade war and rising inflation. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Flying has bounced back, but the whipsaw market conditions, including a new trend of late bookings, has undermined carriers’ ability to forecast demand. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>There’s still a lot of uncertainty about what carriers will be able to charge for tickets, given airline capacity plans are still being adjusted for the crucial holiday travel period, analysts say. An oversupply could gut fares, heaping extra pressure on lower cost carriers more so than larger operators.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Aircraft glut<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>If history is any guide, Spirit’s board will have more than market forces to worry about. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Part of Spirit’s challenge will be how to downsize its fleet as it works to cut costs. It’s expected to encounter tough negotiations with lessors, which supply the bulk of Spirit’s fleet. In bankruptcy, some airlines have been allowed to return planes on lease, though it’s unclear whether Spirit will be able to win approval to pursue that path.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>“With the current board and management, we expect a more aggressive review of costs and negotiation with partners, most notably lessors,” Syth said.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In a filing, Spirit said that it received a written notice of default on Aug 25 from aircraft lessor AerCap Holdings, which said it was terminating dozens of leases on aircraft that were scheduled for delivery to Spirit in the coming years.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Termination would cost Spirit more than US$2 million per lease and apply to dozens of aircraft, the filing said. Spirit disputed the notion of a default and said that the termination of leases was invalid.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>As of Jun 30, Spirit had 215 Airbus A320-family aircraft, including 148 financed under operating leases with terms expiring between 2026 and 2043. It owns 49 planes and has 18 under finance leases.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Spirit may try to return as many as 150 leased planes, Jefferies analyst Sheila Kahyaoglu said. Less than 50 per cent are likely to return to the domestic market, she said, because most carriers already have sufficient capacity to meet demand.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>“This bankruptcy will be harder and look different than last year,” leaders of the Association of Flight Attendants-CWA at Spirit told members on Friday. The airline will likely offer more extended voluntary leaves to employees, the union said. Previously announced pilot furloughs and downgrades will take effect in October and November.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Takeover target<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Airlines operating in Chapter 11 can be particularly vulnerable as takeover targets, and the proceedings could make Spirit more susceptible to a suitor.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The carrier’s filing comes a day after Bloomberg reported that Spirit engaged rival Frontier Group Holdings in high-level talks about the carrier’s ongoing efforts to chart a path forward. Frontier and Bill Franke, the Frontier chairman, have pushed for years for a combination of the two lower-cost carriers.  <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>America West Airlines merged with bankrupt US Airways Group in 2005. The combined company, operating under the US Airways name, acquired American Airlines parent AMR in 2013 to bring that carrier out of bankruptcy.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Spirit was bruised by a 2022 takeover battle between JetBlue Airways and Frontier. Spirit eventually agreed to be acquired by JetBlue in a US$3.8 billion deal, but the combination was blocked in January 2024 by a federal judge on antitrust grounds. BLOOMBERG<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><strong><u><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:24.0pt;font-family:ArialMT;color:#4F81BD;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>8PR </span></u></strong></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><strong><u><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:24.0pt;font-family:ArialMT;color:#FFC000;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>ASIA</span></u></strong></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><b><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Wealthy Americans pour record sums into private credit funds</span></b></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The inflows point to the growing importance that major private investment groups are now placing on individuals, even as inflows from large institutions slow down<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>PRIVATE credit funds are drawing in record sums of capital from everyday investors, offsetting a slowdown from large institutions as wealthy individuals are lured in by the higher returns on offer.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Affluent individual investors in the US have pumped US$48 billion into private credit funds in the first half of this year, already surpassing the entire haul in 2023 and on pace to eclipse 2024’s high-water mark of US$83.4 billion, investment bank RA Stanger has said.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>European investors are also diving in, with assets in so-called evergreen private debt funds across the continent, more than doubling from a year ago to 24 billion euros (S$36.1 billion) at the end of June, said consulting firm Novantigo.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The inflows underscore the growing importance that major private investment groups are now placing on individuals; analysts at rating agency Moody’s are calling it “one of the biggest new growth frontiers in the industry”.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>It also represents just the tip of the spear for groups that had lobbied heavily to open the broader US retirement market up to private equity and credit. Their push culminated in US President Donald Trump’s executive order in August that paved the way for their broader inclusion in 401k plans.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Brad Marshall, Blackstone’s head of private credit, said: “The growth is coming from a very under-penetrated market. Private markets offer investors a premium (over) what they can get in public markets.”<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Fundraising in traditional drawdown, private credit funds has slowed alongside a broader downturn for the leveraged buyout industry, which has struggled to return capital to investors in the years since the Covid-19 pandemic and has, in turn, suffered weaker inflows.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Data from Preqin shows that private credit vehicles pitched to large investors, including endowments and pensions, have raised successively less every year since hitting a peak in 2021.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>New contributions from wealthy individuals, by contrast, have accelerated. They have been spread across a handful of different vehicles, complicating comparisons between firms. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The Stanger data focuses on non-traded business development companies as well as interval funds, which offer redemptions at set periods. Collectively, they are known as evergreen funds, because they do not wind down on a specific date in the future. Investors can also continuously put more money in.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Flows into the vehicles were stable during market swings earlier this year, after US President Donald Trump launched his tariff blitz against most of the US’ largest trading partners. That has bolstered confidence that demand from individuals is durable, and that smaller investors will not race to redeem at the first sign of turbulence.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>John Sweeney, who runs wealth solutions at Brookfield, said: “It reinforced what we’d want to see – people not running from alternatives, but looking at alternatives and saying there was stability there.”  <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Blackstone has long dominated the market, although it is facing intensifying competition from rivals such as Apollo Global Management, Blue Owl, Ares Management and BlackRock’s HPS Investment Partners.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Blackstone’s private credit fund, known as Bcred, has drawn in US$6.5 billion so far this year, and US$11.7 billion over the past 12 months. On the average day markets are open, individual investors are placing more than US$50 million of orders for the fund, the Stanger data shows, putting it at the top of the pack.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Those inflows, supercharged by leverage, have pushed the size of Bcred up more than 50 per cent in the past two years, to US$73 billion in June.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Others are catching up. Apollo’s offering, Apollo Debt Solutions, has raised US$6.4 billion over the past year, and two large funds from Blue Owl have taken in roughly US$7 billion. Ares’ main offering for wealthy individuals, the Ares Strategic Income Fund, has raised US$5 billion.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>A smaller investment management firm, Cliffwater, has won massive share among independent wealth managers. Its fund has gone toe-to-toe with Blackstone, raising nearly US$11 billion in the past year, and now stands at more than US$30 billion.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Blackstone was earlier than many of its rivals as it charged into wealth management offices, pitching major players such as Morgan Stanley and UBS, as well as the independent advisers that direct how millions of Americans save for retirement.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>That resulted in near total market share for its product among other business development companies (BDCs) that are not publicly traded, sitting just below 90 per cent in 2021, noted Stanger. While it has remained the top draw for wealth managers, that figure has fallen to 28 per cent among similar vehicles amid a wave of new fund launches.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Raj Dhanda, global head of wealth management at Ares, said wealth managers were keen to expand the number of funds they could pitch clients, given that Blackstone’s “share of the market was probably uncomfortably high”.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>But he noted that it was still a small set of asset managers drawing in investors. “After a small group of the leading global alternative managers, the flows fall off considerably,” he said.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>European private markets are also seeing a surge of interest from individual investors, sparking a wave of new fund launches across the continent. Novantigo counts 37 private credit evergreen funds in the market, up from just six in 2022. Ares and Blackstone have both been fundraising, and HPS is launching its own vehicle, according to a filing.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Private credit itself has moved into the mainstream after post-crisis regulations limited lending by the traditional banking system. Major asset managers stepped into that void, lending directly to businesses and consumers.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The rapid pace of inflows has caused consternation from some inside the industry, even as their management fees swell. The inflows have materialised alongside a broad market rally, which has led to stiff competition among investors in private and bank syndicated loans. That has weighed on returns, as private lenders compete aggressively to win deals.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>“It’s a tricky investment environment, driven by the imbalance between supply and demand of capital,” Joshua Easterly, a top executive at Sixth Street, said on an earnings call this summer.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>“Competition is elevated, and it’s increasingly difficult to generate outsized returns.”  FINANCIAL TIMES<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><b><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Chanel owners lean on 38 year-old heir to protect their billions</span></b></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>[PARIS] Arthur Heilbronn has all the traits of being groomed to wield power over one of the world’s biggest multi-generational fortunes.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Deep family connections? Check. Ivy League degree? Check. Wall Street smarts? Check.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Now there are growing signs the scion from the dynasty behind the Chanel empire is moving closer to the top of the firm overseeing its US$90 billion fortune. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Heilbronn, 38, has taken on management positions overseeing his and his relatives’ real estate, banking and media investments in the six years since joining Mousse Partners, one of the world’s largest and most discreet family offices. In the latest indication of ascent for the Harvard Business School graduate and ex-Goldman Sachs banker, he became a director earlier this year for one of Mousse’s main holding entities, occupying a role vacated following the death of longtime Chanel executive Michael Rena, according to registry filings.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>He is also the son of Charles Heilbronn, founder of Mousse and the firm’s chairman since 1991. Charles is a half brother of Alain and Gerard Wertheimer, third-generation heirs to the Chanel fortune.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The Wertheimers are grandsons of one of the original business partners of Gabrielle “Coco” Chanel who started the fashion house in 1910. They shared the same mother as Charles, Eliane Heilbronn, who was considered the empire’s matriarch until she died last year. Her sons are all in their 70s. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>A representative for Mousse declined to comment. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The Wertheimers, credited with owning equal shares of closely-held Chanel, each have a net worth of about US$45 billion, according to the Bloomberg billionaires Index. Their fortune has largely held up in the post-pandemic era, even as a downturn in luxury goods hit rivals including LVMH, led by Bernard Arnault, and Kering, controlled by the Pinault family. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Arthur Heilbronn’s rise gives some indication of the succession plans of the media-shy extended family, which has long sought to keep its wealth out of the public eye. Gerard Wertheimer’s son David has started a private equity venture, though there’s no indication that other children of the two heirs are involved with Mousse.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>“They feel less like a family office and more like a private endowment for a luxury empire,” Marc Debois, founder of FO-Next, an advisory firm for family offices, said of Mousse. Among its peers, “what puts them in the true top 1 per cent isn’t size; it’s time; dividend-fed, multi-cycle patience.”<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>At least one-fifth of individuals among the world’s 500 biggest fortunes now have a family office that help to oversee wealth totalling more than US$4 trillion, according to the Bloomberg billionaires Index.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>A recent survey of 317 family office clients at UBS Group found just over half of them have a succession plan in place, with those in the US and South-east Asia most likely to have made those arrangements.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Heilbronn joined Mousse as a director in 2019, moving to managing director a few years later, according to his LinkedIn profile. He’s currently co-head of private equity and venture direct investing with another managing director, Paul Yun. He was named to the supervisory board of Rothschild & Co after Mousse Partners made one of its most high-profile investments to date by joining two other French dynasties in 2023 to help take the bank private. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Chanel’s ultimate holding company is the Wertheimers’ Cayman Islands-based Mousse Investments, which doesn’t reveal financial numbers. Mousse Partners is the investment division and also has offices in Beijing and Hong Kong.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Mousse Investments describes itself as having a “broad range of asset classes in public and private markets” in addition to Chanel. While Mousse doesn’t disclose how much money it controls, some companies have named Mousse Partners as a participant in deals or as a shareholder. That points to investments in stocks, real estate, credit and private equity.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Mousse Partners employs more than three dozen people worldwide and counts former banking analysts from JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo among its employees. Suzi Kwon Cohen joined as chief investment officer almost a decade ago after leading North America private equity for Singapore’s sovereign wealth fund GIC, putting her among the top female executives in the historically male-dominated family office space.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Over the years, Mousse Partners has backed a wide range of startups including mental health provider Brightside Health, digital advertising firm Brandtech Group, biotechnology company Evolved by Nature, food company Harmless Harvest and health-care provider Thirty Madison. Last year Mousse joined the billionaire L’Oreal heiress investing in high-end clothing brand The Row.     <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Not all bets have proved lucrative. Beautycounter failed last year while a pair of Mousse’s public holdings are languishing. The family office has a roughly 8 per cent stake in listed French digital entertainment company NetGem and 5.7 per cent in hair products maker Olaplex Holdings Both companies’ share prices collapsed from their initial public offering levels and haven’t recovered. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Mousse has also been invested for decades in France’s publishing and audiovisual industry through Media-Participations, which owns a range of book publishing, specialised media, cartoon and comic businesses. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The family behind Chanel, a maker of US$970 sunglasses, US$6,500 handbags and US$23,400 J12 watches, has joined other French luxury billionaires with media holdings at home. Bernard Arnault owns newspapers Les Echos and Le Parisien along with the glossy weekly Paris Match. The Pinault clan owns magazines Le Point and Point de Vue. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>While Mousse is not involved in Chanel’s operations, both companies have offices in a glass tower just south of Central Park in Manhattan that’s famed for its pricey rents and list of major financial tenants. Both Arthur and Charles Heilbronn listed their workplace address at that New York premises on Manhattan’s “Billionaires Row,” where Alain Wertheimer has also long-held an office.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Behind closed doors on that street, the next steps in the succession plans for Mousse Partners may already be taking shape, though it’s unlikely anyone in the dynasty behind Chanel will comment publicly on the matter.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>“We’re a very discreet family,” Gerard Wertheimer once said in 2001. “We never talk.” BLOOMBERG<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><b><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Drill, baby, drill: Has Big Oil learnt anything from Deepwater Horizon?</span></b></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The legacy of history’s largest marine spill is back in focus as the industry prepares to go even deeper<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>THIS month 15 years ago, the US government declared the Deepwater Horizon oil well sealed, ending a catastrophic leak that spilled 4.9 million barrels (779 million litres, or 311 Olympic-sized pools’ worth) of crude oil into the Gulf of Mexico.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The disaster – which killed 11 people – was the largest marine oil spill in history, unleashing an environmental crisis that by some estimates harmed hundreds of thousands of marine animals and devastated coastal ecosystems. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Now, as of September 2025, that legacy is being fiercely debated as the oil industry prepares to drill even deeper.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Why is BP returning to the Gulf?<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Despite the controversy, BP is ramping up its commercial ambition in the Gulf of Mexico again. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The company is developing Project Kaskida, a new deep-water well located 250 miles (402 km) from New Orleans, due to start production in 2029. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>When completed, Kaskida may produce 80,000 barrels of oil per day, with potential to access up to 10 billion barrels over its lifetime. It will be the Gulf’s first major oil field since the Deepwater Horizon. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The project will require drilling deeper than the well that failed in 2010 – nearly 1,798 m to the bottom of the Gulf, then another 9,906 m in the rock. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>This move is part of a bigger story: in the years since the Deepwater Horizon spill, the US became the world’s top producer of crude oil in 2018, a mantle the country has held every year since.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>What drives the industry’s high risk appetite?<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The continued corporate focus on deep-water drilling highlights that the risk appetite of major oil firms remains high. This is driven by two key factors. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>First, these locations have long proven a rewarding frontier ground for oil exploration, with governments generally permitting firms to operate there. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In the Gulf of Mexico, for instance, the US government awarded the first new post-disaster deep-water drilling permit in March 2011, less than a year after the Deepwater Horizon spill began.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Second, the world’s oil giants are highly resilient to wide-ranging international risks. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Their scale and profitability, despite fluctuations in oil prices, equip them to absorb major setbacks and respond quickly to new opportunities. Even after incurring tens of billions of dollars in costs and seeing its share price nearly halve in 2010, BP remains a dominant industry player.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>What are the main safety and political concerns?<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The legacy of Deepwater Horizon, however, is much broader than the fate of one company.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The disaster received massive global attention, with an almost immediate regulatory and political backlash. Soon after the oil spill began, several countries including the US, Canada and Norway declared moratoriums on deep-water drilling.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>A decade and a half on, significant concerns continue to be voiced about the safety of deep-water drilling. Several Democratic members of the US Congress have written in collective opposition to the Kaskida project, calling it “an unacceptable threat to Gulf communities, ecosystems, and the climate”.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The legislators highlight BP’s own estimate that a worst-case scenario at Kaskida could release up to four million barrels – “a disaster on par with, or exceeding, the Deepwater Horizon spill”. They also claim that BP “severely underestimates the potential size and duration of a worst-case discharge”.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>This political concern is amplified by many non-governmental organisations too. Jackson Chiappinelli of Earthjustice, an environmental organisation opposed to the new BP project, asserts that “the deeper you go into the ocean to drill, the greater the risk of a spill”.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>What are the long-term environmental and human costs?<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Evidence from other major spills indicates there can be long-term legacy on local ecosystems. A number of species still reportedly have not fully recovered from the 1989 Exxon Valdez disaster, which spilled about 41.6 million litres of oil.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The University of South Florida asserts that multiple fish species have not fully recovered since Deepwater Horizon. The US National Wildlife Federation claims that the impact on wildlife is broader, noting that local dolphin populations, struggling with worsened lung disease and other health issues, could take decades to rebound.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The human cost is also still being measured. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Research from the US National Institute of Health on more than 30,000 workers in the Deepwater Horizon oil spill clean-up found they had an increased propensity for health problems including heart attacks, diabetes, rashes, and other skin conditions.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>So what’s next?<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In this context, the pro-industry “drill, baby, drill” mantra of the second Trump administration raises broad concerns. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The first is that while scientific and technological innovation can improve safety, completely risk-free drilling is unrealistic, given the remote and challenging nature of the work. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The second concern is that intense international focus on the Deepwater Horizon disaster and earlier ones such as Exxon Valdez can obscure a more chronic problem. <o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Significant spills occur regularly around the world with far less attention. A 2006 report concluded that Nigeria’s Niger Delta has experienced the equivalent of an Exxon Valdez leak every year for nearly 50 years.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>It may have been 15 years since the Deepwater Horizon disaster, but the controversy continues. In the absence of further major disasters in the near to mid-term future, deep-water drilling will likely remain a key part of the landscape for years to come.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><b><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Trump’s World Liberty token falls in first day of trading</span></b></span><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>NEW YORK - The digital tokens backing the Trump family’s cryptocurrency venture, World Liberty Financial, fell in value on Sept 1 in their first day of trading.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The World Liberty tokens, known as $WLFI, were sold to investors after the Trump family and its business partners in 2024 launched the venture, a decentralised finance platform that has also issued a stablecoin.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Investors in the tokens voted in July to make them tradable, paving the way for their sale and purchase - and potentially boosting the value of the president’s holdings of them.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Early investors can sell up to 20 per cent of their holdings, World Liberty has said.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The tokens initially traded above US$0.30 (S$0.39) in their Sept 1 debut but later fell in price. They were down about 12 per cent at US$0.246 as of 6.40pm GMT (2.40am on Sept 2 in Singapore), according to CoinGecko data.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>That gave the token a total market capitalisation of just below US$7 billion, making WLFI the 31st largest crypto token in circulation, CoinGecko data showed.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Several of the world’s biggest cryptocurrency exchanges, including Binance, OKX and Bybit, are offering the tokens on their platforms.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Since World Liberty’s launch in 2024, the Trump family has made around US$500 million from the project, according to Reuters calculations based on the company’s terms and conditions, transactions traced by crypto analysis firms, and publicly disclosed deals.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The tokens were not made tradable at their initial sale. Instead, they gave holders the right to vote on some changes to the business, such as its underlying code. Early investors have said the primary draw of $WLFI was the connection to Mr Trump and their expectations that the tokens would grow in value due to his backing.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Making the tokens tradable allows investors to determine their price, enabling speculation, earning trading fees for exchanges that list them, and likely stoking interest from a wider swath of crypto investors.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>World Liberty and Mr Trump’s other crypto businesses have faced criticism from Democratic lawmakers and government ethics experts who say the Trump family’s forays into the cryptocurrency businesses, at the same time as the president reshapes the regulatory framework that governs digital currencies, represent profound conflicts of interest.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></span></p></div><div><p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The White House has said repeatedly that Mr Trump’s assets are in a trust managed by his children and that there are no conflicts of interest. REUTERS<o:p></o:p></span></span></p></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='font-family:"Aptos",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:Aptos;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><hr size=2 width="100%" align=center></span></span></div><p style='line-height:9.0pt'><span style='mso-bookmark:_MailOriginal'><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:9.0pt;font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>This message is intended only for the use of the person to whom it is expressly addressed and for the purpose of the subject of this email and may contain information that is confidential and legally privileged. If you are not the intended recipient, you are hereby notified that any use, reliance on, reference to, review, disclosure or copying of the message and the information it contains for any purpose is prohibited. If you have received this message in error, please notify the sender by reply e-mail of the misdelivery and delete all its contents. <br>Opinions, conclusions and other information in this message that do not relate to the official business of Malayan Banking Berhad shall be understood as neither given nor endorsed by it. </span></span><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:9.0pt;font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></p></div></body></html>

email.file_name: CH_HK_ Lianlian Digitech Co Ltd (2598 HK)_ Capturing stablecoin opportunity in crossborder payments (NOT RATED).eml
email.subject: CH/HK: Lianlian Digitech Co Ltd (2598 HK): Capturing stablecoin opportunity in crossborder payments (NOT RATED)
email.body:
Please click here for report: Lianlian Digitech Co Ltd: Capturing stablecoin opportunity in crossborder payments

Lianlian Digitech Co Ltd (2598 HK): NOT RATED
Market Cap: USD1,438m | Average Daily Value: USD22.4m
Last Traded Price: HKD10.11 ; Potential Target: HKD13.9 ( 37% upside)


Analyst
Manyi Lu manyilu@dbs.com

Capturing stablecoin opportunity in crossborder payments

 

  • Leading cross-border payment player in China with established ecosystem
  • Expect 20%-30% y/y revenue growth and improving profitability in FY25/26F; breakeven in FY26F
  • Wholly owned VATP DFX Lab to expand future stablecoin opportunities
  • Fair value at HKD13.9, with further stablecoin application as re-rating catalyst


Business model to catch stablecoin opportunity. LianLian DigiTech (Lianlian), founded in 2009, is a digital technology company focused on cross-border e-commerce payment services. Lianlian will rely on its wholly owned virtual asset trading platform (VATP) DFX Lab to explore future opportunities in cross-border stablecoin payment scenarios. Its exchange can help cross-border payment clients with the exchange between fiat currencies and stablecoin. This platform will also enable Lianlian to help its cross-border payment clients convert stablecoins back into local currencies in a compliant and legal manner.

 

Expect steady revenue growth and improving profitability. We expect c.30% y/y growth in total payment volume (TPV) for global payments and 10%-15% y/y growth for domestic payments in FY25/26F, with largely stable fee rates. This should drive 20%-30% y/y revenue growth. We also expect profitability to improve due to 1) higher contributions from high-margin cross-border payment vs low-margin domestic payment 2) cost savings from economy of scales and technology application; and 3) narrowing losses in JVs, with core profit expected to break even in FY26F.

 

Recent share price pull-back as an entry point. We believe further development of stablecoin in HK and improving profitability will be a key re-rating catalyst. We apply c.6.8x over its FY26F P/S, which is historical trading average +1 SD, and derive a target price of c.HKD13.9, or 37% upside from the current level.



 

Manyi Lu
manyilu@dbs.com

Analyst
Manyi Lu manyilu@dbs.com

Capturing stablecoin opportunity in crossborder payments

 

  • Leading cross-border payment player in China with established ecosystem
  • Expect 20%-30% y/y revenue growth and improving profitability in FY25/26F; breakeven in FY26F
  • Wholly owned VATP DFX Lab to expand future stablecoin opportunities
  • Fair value at HKD13.9, with further stablecoin application as re-rating catalyst


Business model to catch stablecoin opportunity. LianLian DigiTech (Lianlian), founded in 2009, is a digital technology company focused on cross-border e-commerce payment services. Lianlian will rely on its wholly owned virtual asset trading platform (VATP) DFX Lab to explore future opportunities in cross-border stablecoin payment scenarios. Its exchange can help cross-border payment clients with the exchange between fiat currencies and stablecoin. This platform will also enable Lianlian to help its cross-border payment clients convert stablecoins back into local currencies in a compliant and legal manner.

 

Expect steady revenue growth and improving profitability. We expect c.30% y/y growth in total payment volume (TPV) for global payments and 10%-15% y/y growth for domestic payments in FY25/26F, with largely stable fee rates. This should drive 20%-30% y/y revenue growth. We also expect profitability to improve due to 1) higher contributions from high-margin cross-border payment vs low-margin domestic payment 2) cost savings from economy of scales and technology application; and 3) narrowing losses in JVs, with core profit expected to break even in FY26F.

 

Recent share price pull-back as an entry point. We believe further development of stablecoin in HK and improving profitability will be a key re-rating catalyst. We apply c.6.8x over its FY26F P/S, which is historical trading average +1 SD, and derive a target price of c.HKD13.9, or 37% upside from the current level.
